skills.name: Posture & Alignment
skills.level1Descriptor: Aware of posture but inconsistent execution. Often runs with excessive forward bend at waist or sitting back with hips, disconnecting upper and lower body force transfer. Tends to look down at feet rather than ahead, disrupting spinal alignment. Shoulders frequently tense and raised toward ears. Posture deteriorates significantly when fatigued, particularly in final portions of runs. Requires constant coaching cues to maintain proper alignment and cannot self-correct. Core engagement minimal or absent, leading to excessive lumbar extension during running.
skills.level2Descriptor: Maintains reasonable posture during easy running with occasional lapses. Can implement coaching cues ("run tall," "lean from ankles") with reminders and shows improvement within sessions. Generally keeps head position neutral during steady efforts but reverts to looking down when stressed. Posture breaks down during intense efforts or late in runs as fatigue sets in. Demonstrates understanding of proper alignment but lacks consistency across different intensities and situations. Some core engagement present but not sustained throughout entire run.
skills.level3Descriptor: Consistently maintains good posture during training runs at moderate intensity with proper ankle lean and spinal alignment. Self-corrects when posture slips without external cueing, showing body awareness. Keeps eyes focused forward 10-20 meters ahead, shoulders relaxed and level. Able to maintain form during tempo runs and most race-pace work. Challenges remain at maximum intensity or in deep fatigue states. Core stability adequate for most running situations, preventing excessive lumbar extension. Demonstrates competent biomechanics appropriate for club-level competition.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent posture across all training intensities and race situations with minimal deterioration when fatigued. Maintains optimal alignment throughout races and hard workouts, including final sprint finishes. Demonstrates strong core stability under all conditions, with visible engagement preventing energy leaks. Posture appears efficient and economical with proper forward lean from ankles, neutral spine, and relaxed upper body. Can maintain perfect form even during lactate-inducing efforts. Serves as positive example for training partners and demonstrates proper mechanics on request. Competitive advantage through superior biomechanical efficiency.
skills.level5Descriptor: Optimal biomechanics automatic across all situations, intensities, and fatigue states. Maintains perfect posture even in extreme fatigue states or during final championship sprint finishes against elite competition. Demonstrates world-class running economy through flawless alignment and core stability. Forward lean originates precisely from ankles with shoulders, hips, and ankles in perfect alignment. No conscious thought required to maintain form under any circumstance. Serves as biomechanical model for other athletes and coaches. Elite-level efficiency enables performance at international competition standard.

skills.name: Arm Action & Mechanics
skills.level1Descriptor: Arms move inefficiently with little coordination to leg movement. Frequently crosses arms across body midline, creating wasteful rotation and energy loss. Clenched fists and tense shoulders are common, with tension spreading throughout upper body. Arms may be held too high (above shoulders) or too low with minimal movement. Shows no awareness of arm's role in supporting running efficiency and speed. Cannot maintain any particular arm pattern for more than a few strides. Requires constant coaching on basic arm swing mechanics and relaxation.
skills.level2Descriptor: Basic forward-back movement established but significant technique flaws remain. Still tends to cross midline occasionally, particularly when fatigued or running at higher intensities. Can implement coaching cues ("drive elbows back," "relax hands") with reminders but reverts to old patterns without constant attention. Arms show some coordination with legs but timing often off, particularly during acceleration. Excessive tension still present though improving. Arm action doesn't properly match leg speed - arms too slow during sprints or unnecessarily aggressive during easy running.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good arm mechanics during steady running with arms complementing leg turnover effectively. Generally relaxed with hands loosely cupped ("holding potato chips") and shoulders down. Demonstrates proper elbow drive backward as the active component, with forward swing relaxed. Arms move primarily in sagittal plane (forward-back) with minimal crossing. May lose some form during all-out sprints or when severely fatigued but maintains reasonable mechanics in most situations. Self-corrects when tension creeps in. Demonstrates understanding of arm-leg coordination and can adjust arm action as pace changes.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent arm mechanics across all paces from easy running through maximum sprint speed. Arms drive powerfully when sprinting with aggressive elbow drive backward, while appropriately relaxed for distance running. Strong backward elbow drive maintains upright posture and drives leg turnover. Minimal wasted motion with perfect sagittal plane movement. Hands, wrists, and shoulders remain relaxed despite high intensity. Arms enhance running efficiency measurably rather than just accompanying leg movement. Can demonstrate proper technique to others and self-corrects immediately if form degrades. Competitive advantage through superior arm-leg coordination.
skills.level5Descriptor: Perfect arm-leg coordination automatic across all running speeds and situations. Arms enhance running efficiency at world-class level, contributing meaningfully to elite performance. Completely relaxed yet powerful, with no excess tension or wasted movement visible even during championship finals. Elbow drive backward is explosive during sprints while maintaining perfect relaxation during sustained efforts. Demonstrates biomechanical perfection that serves as model for other athletes. Arms adjust automatically to pace changes without conscious thought. No technical flaws observable even under extreme fatigue or maximum intensity at international competition level.

skills.name: Hip Extension & Drive
skills.level1Descriptor: Minimal hip extension visible during running stride cycle. Leg stays bent throughout stride with little to no straightening behind body during push-off. Appears to "paw" at the ground rather than drive powerfully through complete extension. Weak glute activation with hamstring-dominant running pattern. Limited power generated from hips, resulting in short, choppy strides. May sit back with hips instead of driving them forward through space. Cannot complete triple extension sequence, limiting force production capacity. Stride appears labored and inefficient with obvious weakness in hip extension mechanics.
skills.level2Descriptor: Some hip extension present but incomplete, with leg not fully straightening behind body. Moderate force production from hip extensors but inconsistent execution. Better form when fresh at beginning of runs but deteriorates significantly with fatigue. Shows improvement with coaching cues ("drive the leg back," "finish the push-off") during drills but struggles to transfer to actual running. Beginning to activate glutes but still partially hamstring-dependent. Triple extension sequence attempted but timing and completeness inconsistent. Power output from hips remains moderate, limiting speed potential.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good hip extension during moderate-intensity running with visible leg straightening behind body. Powerful drive visible in sprint work and acceleration phases with strong triple extension. Generally completes extension cycle before initiating knee lift for next stride. Good glute activation providing primary force production with hamstrings in supporting role. Maintains reasonable hip extension mechanics when fatigued though some degradation occurs in final portions of hard efforts. Demonstrates competent force production appropriate for club-level competition. Can execute hip extension drills properly and transfer to running most of the time.
skills.level4Descriptor: Strong, consistent hip extension across all running speeds with exceptional power visible. Powerful glute activation dominates force production with perfect timing of triple extension. Maintains full hip extension mechanics when fatigued, even in final stages of races or hard workouts. Leg fully straightens behind body before knee lift initiates, maximizing propulsion from each stride. Generates elite-level force production through hip extensors, creating competitive advantage in acceleration and maximum velocity. Can demonstrate perfect hip extension technique and explain biomechanics to others. Visible power and efficiency in hip drive distinguishes from competitors at regional-national level.
skills.level5Descriptor: Maximal hip extension with exceptional power production at world-class level. Perfect timing of hip extension and knee lift phases creates biomechanical perfection. Explosive glute activation generates elite-level horizontal and vertical forces. Triple extension flawless during acceleration with optimal force vectors. Maintains perfect hip extension mechanics even during championship sprint finishes against international competition. Serves as biomechanical model demonstrating ideal hip extension technique. Power output from hip extensors among the highest globally, enabling elite performance in sprints, middle distance, or distance events depending on specialization. No technical flaws observable under any circumstance.

skills.name: Knee Drive & Lift
skills.level1Descriptor: Minimal knee lift with leg remaining mostly extended throughout stride cycle. Appears to shuffle or "paw" at ground rather than drive knee upward. No distinction in knee lift between different running speeds - uses same low knee pattern whether jogging or attempting to sprint. Cannot generate high knee drive even when specifically attempting sprint mechanics. Often exhibits back-side mechanics with foot extending behind body before initiating forward swing. Stride length severely limited by inadequate knee lift. Requires constant coaching on knee drive concept but struggles to execute even with cueing.
skills.level2Descriptor: Basic knee lift present but insufficient for running speed attempted. Shows some elevation during sprint efforts but nowhere near optimal height for maximum velocity generation. Can execute high knee drill in isolation but fails to transfer to actual running. Inconsistent knee drive - better when concentrating but reverts to low knee shuffle when focus shifts to other aspects of running. Beginning to understand front-side mechanics concept but execution unreliable. Moderate success with coaching cues but requires frequent reminders. Knee lift appropriate for easy running but inadequate when speed increases.
skills.level3Descriptor: Appropriate knee lift for event and running speed with good differentiation between distance and sprint mechanics. High knee action during sprint work with thigh approaching parallel to ground at full speed. Moderate, economical knee lift during distance running that doesn't waste energy on excessive vertical motion. Demonstrates front-side mechanics competently during acceleration and maximum velocity phases. Can adjust knee lift based on pace requirements without conscious thought in most situations. Generally maintains proper knee drive when fatigued though some degradation in final stages of hard efforts. Biomechanics appropriate for club-regional level competition.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent knee drive across all running applications with optimal height for each situation. Powerful, explosive knee lift during sprints with thigh reaching or exceeding parallel at maximum velocity. Perfect front-side mechanics with knee driving forward and up before foot placement. Economical knee lift during sustained efforts - just enough for efficiency without wasted vertical motion. Maintains optimal knee drive even when severely fatigued or during championship race finishes. Can demonstrate perfect technique in drills and transfer seamlessly to competition. Competitive advantage through superior knee drive mechanics enabling better acceleration and top-end speed. Self-correcting if form degrades.
skills.level5Descriptor: Perfect knee drive mechanics automatic across all speeds and competitive situations. Elite-level knee lift during sprints generates world-class stride length and frequency. Flawless front-side mechanics with explosive upward and forward knee drive. Maintains biomechanically perfect knee action even during Olympic or World Championship finals under extreme fatigue. Demonstrates textbook technique that serves as model for coaches and athletes globally. Knee lift optimizes performance in chosen event specialization - explosive power for sprints or economical efficiency for distance. No technical flaws observable under any circumstance including maximum intensity against world's best athletes.

skills.name: Foot Strike Pattern
skills.level1Descriptor: Heavy heel strike with pronounced overstriding, landing well ahead of center of mass. Creates loud, audible footfalls indicating excessive impact forces. Generates significant braking forces with each stride, reducing efficiency and increasing injury risk. No awareness of foot strike pattern or its importance. Consistent overstriding regardless of running speed. Cannot modify strike pattern even with coaching cues. Inappropriate strike pattern for event specialization - may heel strike while attempting to sprint. Excessive force on landing visible and audible with each step. Demonstrates no understanding of proper foot placement relative to body position.
skills.level2Descriptor: Heel strike still present but less pronounced with reduced overstriding compared to beginner level. Awareness of foot placement developing through coaching. Can modify strike pattern temporarily with constant cueing ("land on ball of foot," "put feet down underneath you") but reverts to heel strike without reminders. Footfalls still moderately loud but improving. Beginning to understand that strike pattern should vary with running speed but inconsistent execution. Shows slight improvement in foot placement relative to center of mass. May achieve appropriate strike pattern in drills but struggles to maintain during continuous running.
skills.level3Descriptor: Appropriate strike pattern for event and running speed with good understanding of biomechanical principles. Midfoot strike during distance running with relatively flat landing near center of mass. Forefoot strike during sprint efforts with proper technique. Relatively quiet footfalls indicating reasonable landing efficiency. Foot lands near or slightly ahead of center of mass with minimal braking forces. Consistent strike pattern within individual running sessions. Can self-correct if strike pattern degrades during fatigue. Demonstrates competent foot placement appropriate for club-level competition. Makes sound decisions about strike pattern based on speed, terrain, and fatigue state.
skills.level4Descriptor: Optimal strike pattern automatic across all running situations with excellent biomechanical efficiency. Very economical foot placement with minimal ground contact time. Quiet, efficient landing technique with virtually no audible footfall. Minimal braking forces due to perfect foot placement relative to center of mass. Strike pattern adjusts appropriately and automatically as pace changes - smooth transition from midfoot at easy pace to forefoot at sprint speeds. Maintains optimal mechanics even when severely fatigued. Demonstrates teaching-level understanding and execution. Competitive advantage through superior landing mechanics reducing energy cost and injury risk. Serves as model for proper strike pattern technique.
skills.level5Descriptor: Biomechanically perfect foot strike for event specialization at world-class level. Exceptionally quick ground contact time with maximum propulsion efficiency. Minimal to zero braking forces with foot placement precisely optimized relative to center of mass. Silent, effortless-appearing landing despite elite-level speeds. Perfect forefoot strike during sprint events or optimal midfoot strike during distance events depending on specialization. Maintains flawless technique during Olympic or World Championship competition under extreme fatigue and pressure. Serves as global technical model for foot strike pattern. Landing mechanics among the most efficient globally, contributing to elite performance capability.

skills.name: Ground Contact Time
skills.level1Descriptor: Prolonged ground contact time with slow, labored push-off from each stride. Appears to stick to ground rather than bounce off quickly. Foot remains in contact excessively long (250+ milliseconds even during faster efforts). Poor ankle stiffness allows excessive dorsiflexion upon landing, absorbing force rather than returning it. Appears to "slog" rather than "bounce" when running. Cannot execute quick feet patterns even with maximal effort. Low running cadence (under 160 steps per minute) reflects long ground contact times. Requires coaching on reactive foot strike concept but struggles to execute. Minimal elastic energy return from tendons due to poor stiffness and technique.
skills.level2Descriptor: Moderate ground contact time with some quickness developing. Can achieve quicker contacts during short bursts when specifically focusing on foot speed but cannot maintain during continuous running. Responds temporarily to coaching cues ("quick feet," "hot coals," "bounce off the ground") but reverts to longer contact times without constant reminding. Ground contact around 200-220 milliseconds during moderate-pace running. Some improvement in ankle stiffness but still allows excessive collapse upon landing. Beginning to understand reactive foot strike concept and can demonstrate briefly in drills. Cadence improving toward 170 steps per minute but inconsistent.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good ground contact time appropriate for training level and event. Quick, reactive foot strikes during sprint work with contact times around 150-180 milliseconds at faster paces. Reasonable ankle stiffness provides adequate elastic energy return. Demonstrates bouncy, springy running quality rather than plodding appearance. Maintains 180+ step per minute cadence during distance running. Can execute quick feet drills properly and transfer partially to continuous running. Contact time increases with fatigue but remains reasonable throughout most efforts. Biomechanically efficient for club-level competition with competent force application during stance phase.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent ground contact time across all running speeds with highly efficient force application. Very quick, reactive foot strikes with optimal ankle stiffness generating superior elastic energy return. Ground contact times approach 120-150 milliseconds during sprint efforts, under 180 milliseconds during distance running. Maintains exceptional quickness even when fatigued. Visibly bouncy, springy running appearance indicating high running economy. Cadence optimal for event (180-185 for distance, very high frequency for sprints). Demonstrates teaching-level foot mechanics and can explain ankle stiffness concept. Competitive advantage through superior ground contact efficiency. Self-corrects if contact time lengthens during fatigue.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class ground contact time demonstrating elite-level reactive strength. Exceptionally quick contacts under 100 milliseconds during maximum velocity sprinting (0.08-0.10 seconds for elite sprinters). Optimal contact times during distance events maximizing running economy. Perfect ankle-foot stiffness generates maximum elastic energy return with minimal energy absorption. Maintains elite-level quickness during Olympic or World Championship finals under extreme fatigue. Demonstrates biomechanical perfection in force application and ground contact efficiency. Serves as global model for reactive foot strike mechanics. Among the quickest ground contact times in the world for chosen event specialization, contributing to international-level performance.

skills.name: Stride Length & Frequency
skills.level1Descriptor: Inefficient stride with either excessive length (overstriding with foot landing far ahead of body) or insufficient length (short, choppy steps). Very low cadence, typically below 160 steps per minute even during moderate-pace running. No optimization of stride length and frequency relationship. May take excessively long strides attempting to run faster, actually creating braking forces and reducing speed. Or conversely, uses short, frantic steps without generating forward propulsion. Cannot adjust stride parameters based on running speed or terrain. Requires coaching on stride mechanics but struggles to implement changes. Demonstrates fundamental misunderstanding of how stride length and frequency combine to create running velocity.
skills.level2Descriptor: Adequate stride mechanics but clearly suboptimal. Cadence improving but still below 170-175 steps per minute for distance running. May still overstride when attempting faster paces or use insufficient stride length when conditions allow for more. Beginning to understand stride optimization concept but execution inconsistent. Responds to coaching cues ("shorten your stride" if overstriding, "open up your stride" during sprints) but changes don't persist without constant reminders. Shows some ability to adjust stride based on speed but not automatic. Demonstrates improvement in matching stride parameters to pace but significant development still needed. Metronome training beginning to establish more consistent cadence.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good stride length and frequency for current ability level with reasonable optimization. Distance runners achieve near 180 steps per minute cadence during training runs. Sprinters demonstrate progressive stride lengthening during acceleration with high frequency at maximum velocity. Appropriate balance between stride length and frequency for body proportions and event. Can adjust stride parameters based on pace requirements without conscious thought in most situations. Foot landing reasonably close to center of mass during distance running, extending stride appropriately during sprints. Biomechanically efficient for club-regional competition level. Self-awareness allows adjustment if stride pattern becomes inefficient during fatigue.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent stride mechanics with optimal balance of length and frequency for event demands. Distance runners maintain 180-185 steps per minute with ideal stride length for their biomechanics and pace. Sprinters achieve exceptional stride frequency (220+ steps/minute at max velocity) while maximizing stride length through powerful hip extension and leg drive. Perfect optimization for individual anthropometry - neither overstriding nor leaving speed on table with insufficient stride length. Maintains optimal stride parameters even when severely fatigued. Can explain stride mechanics to others and demonstrate across full spectrum of running speeds. Competitive advantage through superior stride efficiency. Adjusts automatically to terrain changes (hills, curves, surface) without conscious thought.
skills.level5Descriptor: Perfect stride optimization automatic across all speeds and competitive situations. Elite distance runners achieve 180-185 optimal cadence with maximal economical stride length. World-class sprinters exceed 240 steps per minute at maximum velocity while generating exceptional stride length (2.4+ meters for elite male sprinters). Demonstrates textbook stride mechanics that serve as global model. Maintains biomechanically perfect parameters during Olympic or World Championship finals under extreme pressure and fatigue. Stride length achieved through exceptional power and technique, not overstriding. Frequency optimal for event specialization. Among the most efficient stride patterns globally, contributing to world-class running economy and speed. No technical flaws observable under any circumstance.

skills.name: Core Stability During Running
skills.level1Descriptor: Minimal core engagement during running with excessive trunk and pelvic movement. Visible excessive rotation of shoulders and hips, particularly when fatigued. Lower back arches excessively (anterior pelvic tilt and lumbar extension) creating energy leaks and poor force transfer. Torso flexes and extends noticeably with each stride rather than maintaining stability. Cannot maintain "chin to belt buckle" core brace for more than a few strides. Posture collapses quickly as core fatigues, leading to sitting back with hips or excessive forward bend at waist. Demonstrates fundamental weakness in core musculature and no understanding of core's role in running efficiency. Running appears disjointed with poor connection between upper and lower body.
skills.level2Descriptor: Some core engagement present but inconsistent and inadequate for optimal running. Can brace core with coaching reminders ("engage your core," "chin to belt buckle") but doesn't maintain automatically. Moderate trunk stability during easy running but noticeable degradation when pace increases or fatigue sets in. Excessive lumbar extension still visible, particularly in later stages of runs. Some rotational movement present though less extreme than beginner level. Beginning to understand core stability concept and shows improvement when focusing on it. Cannot maintain core engagement throughout entire run - tends to fatigue midway through sessions. Shows promise but needs significant development in core strength and endurance.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good core stability during most running situations with effective trunk control. Maintains stable pelvis and spine during steady running with minimal excessive rotation or extension. Demonstrates proper core bracing automatically during normal training paces. Some degradation in core stability during very hard efforts or extreme fatigue but maintains reasonable control. Efficient force transfer from lower body through stable trunk enables competent running economy. Can self-correct when core engagement lapses. Demonstrates understanding of core's role and can engage properly without external cueing in most situations. Appropriate core stability for club-regional level competition. May still experience some breakdown in final stages of championship races or after prolonged hard efforts.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent core stability across all running intensities and durations with minimal energy leaks. Strong, consistent core bracing maintains optimal trunk position even during maximal sprint efforts and severe fatigue states. Visible core engagement prevents excessive rotation, flexion, extension, or lateral movement. Maintains perfect force transfer from powerful leg drive through stable trunk to forward propulsion. Core strength endures throughout races and hard workouts without meaningful degradation. Can demonstrate proper core engagement and explain its biomechanical importance to others. Competitive advantage through superior core stability enabling better running economy and power transfer. Self-correcting if core engagement weakens, though this rarely occurs. Serves as model for core stability during running.
skills.level5Descriptor: Perfect core stability automatic across all situations including Olympic and World Championship competition. Exceptional core strength and endurance maintains flawless trunk control even during championship sprint finishes or final kilometers of distance races under extreme fatigue. Zero energy leaks through trunk with optimal force transfer from lower body to forward propulsion. Core engagement requires no conscious thought and never degrades regardless of intensity, duration, or fatigue. Demonstrates world-class biomechanical efficiency with trunk serving as perfect stable platform for leg drive. Among the most stable running cores globally, contributing to elite-level running economy and power application. Serves as global model for core stability during running. No technical flaws observable under any circumstance including maximum intensity against world's best athletes.

skills.name: Ankle Control & Stiffness
skills.level1Descriptor: Poor ankle control with excessive collapse (dorsiflexion) upon landing, absorbing force rather than returning it elastically. Ankle too compliant, allowing foot to sink into ground during stance phase. Or conversely, may demonstrate rigid ankle lacking natural spring mechanism. No active dorsiflexion during swing phase - foot may dangle loosely or demonstrate poor positioning. Cannot maintain proper ankle position through fatigue. Demonstrates weak intrinsic foot musculature and poor proprioception. Running appears heavy and stuck to ground rather than bouncy and reactive. Minimal elastic energy return from Achilles tendon-calf complex due to poor stiffness regulation. Requires coaching on ankle positioning and stiffness concept but struggles to understand or implement.
skills.level2Descriptor: Some ankle control developing but inconsistent stiffness regulation. Better dorsiflexion during swing phase when concentrating but often reverts to poor positioning. Ankle stiffness improving slightly with training but still allows excessive collapse upon landing or demonstrates too much rigidity. Can implement coaching cues ("pull toes up," "bounce off ground") temporarily but doesn't maintain without constant reminding. Beginning to develop some elastic recoil capacity but still absorbs too much force. Moderate success during drills specifically targeting ankle mechanics but struggles to transfer to continuous running. Shows improvement trajectory but significant development still needed. Running starting to appear slightly more springy but far from optimal reactive quality.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good ankle control with appropriate dorsiflexion during swing phase preparing for landing. Reasonable ankle stiffness during stance phase provides adequate elastic energy return without excessive collapse. Demonstrates natural springy quality when running, particularly during faster efforts. Foot positioned properly throughout stride cycle in most situations. Ankle stiffness appropriate for running speed - slightly more compliant during distance running, stiffer during sprints. Some degradation in ankle control when severely fatigued but maintains reasonable mechanics throughout most efforts. Competent ankle mechanics contribute to decent running economy for club-level competition. Can feel difference between proper and improper ankle positioning and adjust accordingly in most situations.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent ankle control and stiffness regulation across all running speeds and conditions. Active, deliberate dorsiflexion during swing phase positions foot optimally for landing. Ankle stiffness during stance phase perfectly balanced - allows minimal necessary compliance while maximizing elastic energy return. Highly developed Achilles tendon-calf complex provides superior spring-like behavior. Running appears highly reactive and bouncy with visible elastic recoil. Maintains optimal ankle mechanics even when severely fatigued. Ankle stiffness adjusts automatically based on running speed, terrain, and footwear without conscious thought. Competitive advantage through superior ankle mechanics contributing to running economy and ground contact efficiency. Can demonstrate and explain ankle control to others. Serves as model for proper ankle function during running.
skills.level5Descriptor: Perfect ankle control and stiffness regulation automatic at world-class level. Optimal dorsiflexion-plantar flexion control throughout stride cycle maximizes efficiency and power. Elite-level ankle stiffness provides maximum elastic energy return with minimal energy absorption. Achilles tendon-calf complex demonstrates exceptional spring-like properties contributing to world-class running economy. Maintains flawless ankle mechanics during Olympic or World Championship finals under extreme fatigue and intensity. Demonstrates biomechanical perfection that serves as global model. Ankle function optimized for chosen event specialization. Among the most efficient ankle mechanics globally, contributing to international-level performance capability. No technical flaws observable under any circumstance. Running economy measurably enhanced by superior ankle-foot complex function.

skills.name: Running Relaxation & Efficiency
skills.level1Descriptor: Excessive tension throughout body during all running, even easy efforts. Face scrunched, jaw clenched, shoulders hunched up toward ears, hands in tight fists. Running appears forced, strained, and labored regardless of actual pace. Excessive vertical oscillation (bouncing up and down) wastes energy. Unnecessary movements visible - flailing arms, excessive head movement, twisting torso. Cannot maintain any relaxation for more than few strides before tension creeps back. Breathing appears strained and uncontrolled. Demonstrates no understanding of relaxation's role in running efficiency. Tenses up dramatically when attempting faster paces, actually reducing speed through muscular conflict. Appears to work very hard to run at moderate paces that should feel comfortable.
skills.level2Descriptor: Some relaxation during easy running but significant tension remains and increases dramatically with pace. Can implement relaxation cues ("relax your jaw," "drop your shoulders," "loosen your hands") temporarily but reverts to tension quickly without constant reminding. Face and shoulders still show considerable tightness during moderate and hard efforts. Beginning to understand relaxation concept but struggles to maintain while running hard. Shows some reduction in wasteful movements but efficiency still poor compared to competent runners. Breathing rhythm choppy and irregular. Relaxation deteriorates rapidly with fatigue. May achieve brief periods of smooth running but cannot sustain. Demonstrates improvement trajectory but significant development needed.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good relaxation and efficiency during steady running with generally smooth appearance. Maintains loose jaw, relaxed shoulders, and cupped hands during normal training paces. Demonstrates economical movement without excessive vertical oscillation or unnecessary motions. Breathing controlled and rhythmic at moderate intensities. Some tension visible during very hard efforts or extreme fatigue but maintains reasonable relaxation in most situations. Can recognize when tension creeps in and actively relax without external cueing. Running appears fluid and controlled rather than strained. Efficiency appropriate for club-level competition with decent running economy. May tighten up slightly in final stages of races but doesn't completely lose relaxed form.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent relaxation across all running intensities with smooth, efficient movement quality. Maintains relaxed facial muscles, jaw, shoulders, and hands even during maximal sprint efforts. Demonstrates "relaxed intensity" - working hard but without counterproductive tension. Minimal wasted movement with economical running form contributing to superior running economy. Controlled breathing pattern maintained across wide range of intensities. Appears smooth and effortless even when running at near-maximal effort. Can maintain relaxation throughout entire races and workouts despite severe fatigue. Self-monitoring prevents tension from developing. Competitive advantage through superior economy and efficiency. Serves as model for smooth, relaxed running form. Can coach others on relaxation techniques and demonstrate across full speed spectrum.
skills.level5Descriptor: Perfect relaxation and efficiency automatic at world-class level appearing effortless despite elite speeds. Maintains complete relaxation of non-working muscles during Olympic or World Championship finals under extreme intensity and pressure. Demonstrates biomechanically perfect economy of movement with zero wasted energy. Facial expression calm and controlled even during championship sprint finishes. Running appears smooth, fluid, and almost easy despite world-record pace or maximum sprint velocity. Among the most economical and efficient running forms globally. Serves as international model for relaxed, efficient running mechanics. Contributes meaningfully to world-class running economy through superior relaxation ability. No visible tension or wasted movement observable under any circumstance including maximum intensity against world's best competitors.

skills.name: Acceleration Ability
skills.level1Descriptor: Little acceleration ability with slow, labored speed development from start. Stands upright immediately rather than maintaining low, powerful drive position. Weak force production during push-off limits acceleration rate. No understanding of proper acceleration mechanics - no forward lean, inadequate triple extension, poor ground contact angles. Stride length increases minimally during acceleration phase. Appears to jog rather than explosively accelerate. Cannot maintain any forward lean beyond first step. Takes 50+ meters to reach near-maximum velocity. Demonstrates fundamental lack of power and technical knowledge. Loses ground dramatically to competitors in acceleration phase of sprints or during break-aways in distance events.
skills.level2Descriptor: Basic acceleration present but technically flawed and lacking power. Some forward lean attempted but often too upright too soon, typically rising by 10 meters. Moderate force production enables reasonable speed development but not competitive at higher levels. Can implement coaching cues ("stay low," "drive, drive, drive") temporarily during drills but struggles to transfer to actual races. Some triple extension visible but incomplete and inconsistent. Stride length builds somewhat but not optimally progressive. Understands acceleration should differ from upright sprinting but execution poor. Reaches moderate velocity by 30-40 meters but rate of acceleration slow. Shows improvement potential but needs significant power and technical development.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good acceleration mechanics with appropriate lean angle and powerful drive phase. Maintains progressive forward lean through first 10-20 meters before gradually rising to upright position. Powerful triple extension visible with strong ground contact and backward-directed force. Stride length builds progressively and appropriately throughout acceleration zone. Demonstrates competent acceleration technique enabling competitive performance at club-regional level. Reaches near-maximum velocity by 40-50 meters. Some breakdown may occur under extreme fatigue or championship pressure but generally reliable. Can execute acceleration drills properly and transfer to racing situations. Understands front-side mechanics emphasis during acceleration.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent acceleration with strong horizontal force production and technically sound mechanics. Maintains optimal lean angles (45-55 degrees early, gradually rising) throughout acceleration phase. Explosive triple extension generates rapid velocity increase. Powerful ground contacts with force vectors optimally directed for maximum acceleration. Stride length progression perfect - controlled early steps building to full sprint stride by 30-40 meters. Reaches maximum or near-maximum velocity by 40 meters in 100m sprint. Competitive advantage through superior acceleration ability - gains significant ground on competitors during drive phase. Maintains excellent technique even when fatigued. Can demonstrate perfect acceleration mechanics and coach others. Elite-level explosive ability evident.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class acceleration demonstrating exceptional power and perfect technique. Explosive first steps with optimal 45-55 degree lean and maximal horizontal force production. Reaches maximum velocity in minimal distance (35-40 meters or less). Biomechanically perfect throughout acceleration - optimal lean angles, flawless triple extension, perfect force vectors, ideal stride progression. Demonstrates elite-level explosive strength enabling dominating acceleration performance at international competition. Maintains perfect technique during Olympic or World Championship finals under maximum pressure. Among fastest accelerators globally for chosen event. Serves as international model for acceleration mechanics. Gains decisive competitive advantage through superior acceleration ability. No technical flaws observable under any circumstance.

skills.name: Maximum Velocity
skills.level1Descriptor: Low maximum velocity with poor mechanics at top speed. Appears tense and forced when attempting maximum effort rather than relaxed and fluid. Demonstrates back-side mechanics with foot reaching behind body before ground contact rather than proper front-side technique. Excessive ground contact time and inadequate knee lift limit velocity potential. Arms crossing midline or poorly coordinated with legs. Cannot maintain any particular velocity - constantly decelerating and re-accelerating. Limited speed capacity restricts performance across all running events. Velocity reached far below potential for age and training level. Breathing pattern irregular and strained during maximum efforts.
skills.level2Descriptor: Moderate maximum velocity for age and training level with basic mechanics present but significant flaws evident. Some front-side mechanics visible during top speed running but inconsistent - may revert to back-side reaching. Moderate tension remains in upper body limiting full velocity expression. Some knee lift present but insufficient for optimal maximum velocity generation. Ground contact time excessive compared to elite standards. Leg turnover rate moderate. Can implement coaching cues ("relax," "high knees," "quick feet") during drills but struggles to maintain during actual maximum velocity running. Shows improvement trajectory but needs considerable development. Speed reserve limited.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good maximum velocity relative to competition level with sound mechanics at top speed. Demonstrates proper front-side mechanics with knee drive forward before foot placement. Reasonably relaxed upper body despite high intensity effort. Good knee lift and leg turnover rate for ability level. Ground contact time adequate though not elite. Maintains maximum velocity for reasonable duration (10-20 meters) before deceleration. Upright torso position with coordinated arm-leg action. Velocity appropriate for club-regional competition. Can execute maximum velocity drills and transfer to racing. Some breakdown may occur with extreme fatigue but generally maintains mechanics well.
skills.level4Descriptor: High maximum velocity with excellent mechanics maintained at top speed. Perfect front-side mechanics with explosive knee drive and optimal foot placement. Relaxed and fluid appearance despite near-maximal intensity. Exceptional stride frequency combined with good stride length. Very short ground contact time approaching elite standards. Maintains top speed for extended duration (20-30+ meters) with minimal deceleration. Demonstrates relaxed intensity - working maximally but without counterproductive tension. Competitive advantage in maximum velocity events and phases. Can maintain excellent mechanics even when fatigued. Serves as model for proper maximum velocity technique. Elite-level top-end speed capability.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class maximum velocity demonstrating perfect mechanics automatic at top speed. Exceptional stride frequency (240+ steps per minute) combined with elite stride length. Ground contact time under 0.10 seconds with maximum force production. Flawless front-side mechanics with explosive knee drive and perfect foot placement. Appears completely relaxed and effortless despite running at world-record pace or near personal maximum. Maintains elite-level top speed throughout maximum velocity zone with minimal deceleration. Biomechanically perfect at top speed - serves as international model. Among fastest maximum velocities globally. Performs at Olympic or World Championship level in maximum velocity events. No technical flaws observable under any circumstance including finals against world's best sprinters.

skills.name: Speed Endurance
skills.level1Descriptor: Very limited speed endurance with significant deceleration in second half of even short sprints. Cannot maintain pace over distances beyond 60-80 meters without dramatic slowing. Mechanics break down severely when combining speed and fatigue - form collapses, stride shortens drastically, arms flail. Experiences severe tying up (excessive muscle tension and acidosis) attempting to sustain speed. Cannot complete 200m at anything approaching maximum effort without walking or near-walking in final portion. Demonstrates fundamental lack of lactate tolerance and speed endurance capacity. Recovery between sprint repetitions very prolonged. Shows no ability to maintain technique under metabolic stress.
skills.level2Descriptor: Basic speed endurance developing but limited capacity. Can maintain moderate speeds over 100-150 meters but significant fade visible and measurable. 200m very challenging with pronounced deceleration in final 50-80 meters. 400m extremely difficult, often requiring 60+ seconds and involving walking or near-complete breakdown. Mechanical deterioration significant when combining speed and fatigue though not complete collapse. Tying up common in longer sprints. Can complete speed endurance workouts but requires extended recovery between repetitions. Shows improvement trajectory with training but substantial development needed. Lactate tolerance low but trainable.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good speed endurance for competition level with limited deceleration over 200 meters. Can complete competitive 400m with reasonable pace maintenance, though some slowing inevitable in final 100m. Technique deteriorates moderately under speed-fatigue combination but doesn't collapse completely. Demonstrates adequate lactate tolerance for club-regional level competition. Can maintain 80-85% of maximum velocity over 200m. Recovery between speed endurance repetitions reasonable. Completes race-specific workouts (200m, 300m, 400m intervals) at appropriate intensities. Shows good training response to speed endurance work. Mechanical breakdown manageable even when experiencing metabolic stress.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent speed endurance with ability to maintain high percentage (85-90%) of maximum velocity through 200m and sustain competitive speed throughout 400m. Minimal mechanical breakdown when fatigued - maintains stride length, arm action, and postural control despite intense metabolic stress. Strong lactate tolerance enables high-level performance in longer sprints and hurdle events. Demonstrates competitive advantage in 200m/400m through superior speed maintenance. Can complete demanding speed endurance workouts (multiple 300m or 400m repetitions) with controlled rest and maintain quality. Recovery capacity strong. Minimal deceleration visible even in championship 200m/400m finals. Serves as model for speed endurance training and execution.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class speed endurance demonstrating exceptional ability to maintain velocity under extreme metabolic stress. Can sustain 90-95% of maximum velocity through 200m and maintain elite pace throughout 400m with minimal deceleration. Perfect technique preservation when fatigued - no mechanical breakdown visible even during Olympic or World Championship 200m/400m finals. Exceptional lactate tolerance enables dominating performance in longer sprints. Among the best globally at maintaining speed under metabolic stress. Demonstrates biomechanical perfection even when experiencing severe acidosis. Recovery ability elite-level. Serves as international model for speed endurance. Competitive advantage decisive in 200m/400m/hurdle events at highest level. No technical flaws observable despite extreme physiological stress.

skills.name: Power Output
skills.level1Descriptor: Low power output with weak force production and slow movement speeds. Cannot generate explosive movements in any context - starts, jumps, throws, or sprints all appear labored and weak. Demonstrates poor rate of force development, taking excessive time to achieve even moderate force levels. Triple extension weak and incomplete during running, jumping, or explosive drills. Shows minimal reactive strength in plyometric activities - lands heavily, cannot rebound quickly. Strength levels low for age and body weight. No training history in power development activities. Appears slow and unathletic across all explosive movements. Cannot execute basic plyometric exercises (box jumps, bounding, depth jumps) with any proficiency or power.
skills.level2Descriptor: Moderate power output developing with some explosive capability emerging. Can generate reasonable force but rate of force development slow - takes time to achieve peak force. Shows improvement with power training (plyometrics, Olympic lift variations, sprints) but still well below advanced levels. Triple extension improving but not powerful or explosive. Reactive strength developing - can complete basic plyometric exercises but contacts prolonged and rebound limited. Strength improving toward moderate levels. Power visible in some contexts but inconsistent and not competition-level. Demonstrates understanding of explosive intent but execution limited by current neuromuscular development. Shows clear improvement trajectory with appropriate training.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good power output for competition level enabling competitive acceleration and sprinting. Demonstrates solid force production with reasonable rate of force development. Can execute explosive movements competently - powerful starts, good acceleration, adequate jumping ability. Triple extension strong during running and explosive activities. Reactive strength good - demonstrates reasonable plyometric ability with moderate ground contact times and adequate rebound height. Strength levels appropriate for body weight and sport demands. Power training experience evident in movement quality. Enables club-regional level performance in speed-power events. Can complete advanced plyometric exercises (depth jumps, multiple bounds, hurdle hops) with reasonable proficiency.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent power output with high force production and rapid rate of force development. Demonstrates explosive capability across all movements - exceptional starts, rapid acceleration, powerful jumping and bounding. Triple extension highly powerful and complete, generating elite-level forces. Reactive strength exceptional - minimal ground contact times, maximal rebound heights, elastic quality evident. Strength levels high relative to body weight. Extensive power training background evident. Can execute advanced plyometrics (depth jumps from high boxes, single-leg bounding, complex sequences) with explosive power. Competitive advantage through superior power production. Movement quality explosive and athletic. Approaching elite-level power capacity for chosen events.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class power output among the highest globally for athletics. Exceptional force production combined with maximum rate of force development. Demonstrates elite-level explosive capability in all contexts - starts among fastest globally, acceleration exceptional, jumping ability outstanding. Triple extension generates maximum possible forces with perfect technique. Reactive strength at international level - ground contact times minimal, rebound heights maximal, elastic qualities perfect. Strength-to-weight ratio exceptional. Power training optimized over years creating elite neuromuscular qualities. Can demonstrate plyometric exercises at teaching level with maximum power. Serves as international model for power production. Enables Olympic or World Championship performance in power-dependent events. Among most powerful athletes globally in chosen specialization.

skills.name: Starting Blocks Technique
skills.level1Descriptor: Unfamiliar with starting blocks showing poor setup and execution. Block spacing random or copied without understanding individual biomechanics. Set position weak - hips too low or too high, weight distribution poor, body position unstable. Weak block clearance with inadequate force production - appears to step out of blocks rather than explode. Stands upright immediately after gun rather than maintaining drive position. First steps reaching forward (overstriding) instead of driving backward and down. Slow reaction time to gun with delayed processing. Frequent false starts due to poor gun anticipation or body control. Looks down at track immediately after start. Cannot maintain consistent technique across multiple start attempts. Demonstrates no understanding of proper block start mechanics or their importance for race performance.
skills.level2Descriptor: Basic block start ability with setup and execution improving but not optimal. Block spacing adequate but may not be individualized - uses generic spacing without testing alternatives. Set position reasonable but inconsistent - hip height varies, weight distribution imperfect, some instability in hold. Moderate push from blocks but not explosive. Some forward lean maintained after gun but often rises too quickly (by 3-5 meters). First step improved but may still reach somewhat forward rather than optimal backward drive. Reaction time improving but not competitive at higher levels. Occasional false starts, particularly under pressure. Can implement coaching corrections during practice but struggles to maintain under competition stress. Shows improvement trajectory but needs considerable refinement.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good block start mechanics with consistent setup and execution. Block spacing individualized and tested for optimal configuration. Set position solid and consistent - hips elevated above shoulders (front knee 90-110 degrees, rear knee 120-140 degrees), weight properly distributed, body position stable and powerful. Powerful block clearance with strong push from both blocks simultaneously. Maintains appropriate forward lean through first 10+ meters. First step drives backward and down creating optimal acceleration. Reasonable reaction time (0.16-0.20 seconds) competitive at club-regional level. Rare false starts with good gun discipline. Can maintain technique under competition pressure. Demonstrates competent starts enabling strong race beginnings. Self-correcting if setup or execution degrades.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent block start technique with optimal setup and explosive execution. Block spacing perfectly individualized through extensive testing and refinement. Set position optimal and rock-solid - perfect hip height, ideal weight distribution, maximum stability and coil. Explosive block clearance with maximum horizontal force production - can see blocks move from push force. First step perfectly executes backward and down drive. Maintains optimal forward lean throughout entire acceleration phase. Fast reaction time (0.13-0.16 seconds) creating competitive advantage. Virtually no false starts - perfect gun discipline. Technique holds under championship pressure. Can demonstrate perfect starts and explain biomechanics to others. Elite-level first 10 meters from blocks. Serves as model for starting technique.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class starting ability demonstrating perfect technique and exceptional reaction. Block setup optimized through years of refinement for individual biomechanics. Set position biomechanically perfect - ideal angles, maximum coil, perfect stability. Exceptionally fast reaction time (0.11-0.14 seconds) among quickest globally while maintaining legal starts. Explosive block clearance generates maximum possible horizontal force - among most powerful starts in the world. First step and acceleration phase flawless. Maintains perfect technique during Olympic or World Championship finals under maximum pressure. Serves as international model for block start mechanics. Decisive competitive advantage through superior starting ability. No technical flaws observable. Gun discipline perfect despite racing on the edge of legal reaction time. Among the best starters globally.

skills.name: Aerobic Capacity (VO2 Max)
skills.level1Descriptor: Limited aerobic capacity appropriate for untrained state or early-stage youth athlete. Adult beginner typically below 40 ml/kg/min (men) or 35 ml/kg/min (women). Youth athlete showing age-appropriate developing capacity but minimal training adaptation. Becomes breathless quickly during sustained efforts. Cannot maintain even moderate paces for extended durations. Recovery prolonged between efforts due to limited oxygen delivery and utilization capacity. Demonstrates significant potential for improvement with consistent aerobic training. Performance in middle-distance and distance events severely limited by low aerobic ceiling. May struggle to complete even 800m at anything beyond slow pace. Cardiovascular system untrained with limited oxygen transport and utilization capacity.
skills.level2Descriptor: Improving aerobic capacity showing training response. Adult recreational runner: 40-50 ml/kg/min (men), 35-45 ml/kg/min (women). Youth athlete showing improvement with consistent training. Can sustain moderate efforts for reasonable durations (15-30 minutes) though pace remains submaximal. Recovery between interval efforts improving but still requires substantial rest. Cardiovascular adaptations beginning - stroke volume increasing, capillary density improving, mitochondrial function developing. Performance in endurance events limited but improving steadily. Can complete 800m-1500m at moderate competitive pace. Demonstrates clear improvement trajectory with regular aerobic training. Still has considerable ceiling for improvement with continued training progression.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good aerobic capacity for trained club-level athlete. Adult: 50-60 ml/kg/min (men), 45-55 ml/kg/min (women). Youth: above-average for age group with consistent training background. Can sustain high-moderate efforts for extended durations (30-60+ minutes). Recovery between hard efforts reasonable, can complete challenging interval sessions. Cardiovascular system well-adapted - good cardiac output, adequate oxygen carrying capacity, reasonable capillary and mitochondrial density. Competitive at local-regional level in middle-distance and distance events. Can race 800m through 10,000m competently at club level. Demonstrates solid training response and consistent performance. Further improvement possible but requires advanced training methods and greater volume.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent aerobic capacity approaching elite levels. Adult: 60-70 ml/kg/min (men), 55-65 ml/kg/min (women). Youth: exceptional for age, high-level junior competitor. Multi-year consistent training background evident. Can sustain hard efforts for extended durations with excellent work capacity. Recovery between high-intensity efforts quick, enabling demanding training loads. Cardiovascular system highly developed - large stroke volume, high oxygen carrying capacity, extensive capillary networks, high mitochondrial density. Competitive at regional-national level in endurance events. Demonstrates national-level competitor potential or achievement. Training capacity high - can handle substantial training volumes and intensities. Aerobic ceiling high enough to support elite-level performance with continued development.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class aerobic capacity at international competition level. Adult: 70-85+ ml/kg/min (men), 65-75+ ml/kg/min (women). Youth: elite junior with international potential. Cardiovascular system maximally developed - exceptional cardiac output, optimal oxygen carrying capacity, extensive capillary networks, maximal mitochondrial density and function. Can sustain very high work rates for extended durations. Recovery ability exceptional, enabling world-class training loads. Competitive at Olympic or World Championship level in endurance events. Among highest VO2 max values globally for endurance athletes. Enables elite performance in events from 800m through marathon depending on other physiological factors (lactate threshold, running economy). Represents genetic potential combined with optimal long-term training. Aerobic ceiling among the highest in the world.

skills.name: Lactate Threshold
skills.level1Descriptor: Low lactate threshold at approximately 55-65% of VO2 max, typical of untrained individual. Can sustain lactate threshold pace for very limited duration, typically less than 10 minutes before fatigue forces slowing. Minimal training adaptation in oxidative capacity, capillary density, or mitochondrial function. No clear sense of threshold intensity - cannot distinguish between easy aerobic running and threshold effort by feel. Performance in sustained efforts poor relative to maximal capacity - large gap between VO2 max and sustainable pace. Becomes uncomfortable quickly when approaching threshold and must slow down. Blood lactate accumulates rapidly above moderate intensities. Demonstrates significant potential for improvement as threshold is highly trainable, often improving more rapidly than VO2 max with proper training.
skills.level2Descriptor: Improving lactate threshold at approximately 65-75% of VO2 max showing training response. Can sustain threshold pace for 15-20 minutes with focused effort. Beginning to develop threshold awareness - can recognize the comfortably hard intensity that characterizes threshold running, though consistency imperfect. Oxidative capacity improving with training - better capillary density, increasing mitochondrial function. Performance in sustained efforts improving but still well below competitive standards. Gap between VO2 max and threshold pace narrowing with training. Some training effect visible but considerable development needed. Responds well to threshold training (tempo runs, cruise intervals) with measurable improvement. Shows clear improvement trajectory suggesting good training responsiveness.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good lactate threshold at approximately 75-80% of VO2 max, typical of trained club-level runner. Can sustain threshold pace for 20-30 minutes during tempo runs or race efforts. Good sense of threshold effort - can self-regulate to appropriate intensity without constant external feedback. Oxidative capacity well-developed through consistent training - adequate capillary density, good mitochondrial function, reasonable lactate clearance capacity. Performance in endurance events competitive at club-regional level. Can race 5K-10K at paces approximating lactate threshold. Threshold training has elevated this physiological marker meaningfully. Can complete threshold workouts consistently (tempo runs, cruise intervals, progression runs). Further improvement possible but requires continued high-quality threshold training and time.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent lactate threshold at approximately 80-88% of VO2 max, approaching elite levels. Can sustain threshold pace for 30-60 minutes in training and racing contexts. Excellent threshold awareness - can precisely regulate effort to threshold intensity by feel. Highly developed oxidative capacity - extensive capillary networks, high mitochondrial density and function, superior lactate clearance mechanisms. Performance in endurance events competitive at regional-national level. Can sustain paces very close to VO2 max for extended durations - minimal gap between threshold and maximum. Race performances reflect high threshold - can run half marathon at pace very close to 10K pace. Demonstrates advanced training status with years of consistent threshold development. Further improvements incremental but possible with optimal training.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class lactate threshold at approximately 85-95% of VO2 max, among highest globally. Can sustain threshold pace for extended durations exceeding 60 minutes - can run half marathon or even marathon at or very near lactate threshold. Perfect threshold awareness - can regulate to precise intensities by feel without external monitoring. Maximally developed oxidative capacity - exceptional capillary density, maximal mitochondrial function, elite-level lactate clearance. Performance at Olympic or World Championship level in endurance events. Minimal gap between lactate threshold and VO2 max - can sustain very high percentages of maximum for extended time. Demonstrates elite training status with years of optimal threshold development. Among the best globally at sustaining high-intensity efforts. Threshold so high that racing speeds approach maximum aerobic capacity, creating decisive competitive advantage.

skills.name: Running Economy
skills.level1Descriptor: Poor running economy due to inefficient mechanics and low training volume. High energy cost for given pace - uses significantly more oxygen than economical runners at same speed. Wasteful movement patterns clearly visible: excessive vertical oscillation (bouncing), poor posture, inefficient arm action, overstriding, tension throughout body. Biomechanically inefficient with multiple technical flaws. No economy-specific training history. Short training background limits neuromuscular adaptations that improve economy. High relative effort required for moderate paces. Cardiovascular and metabolic systems working hard to sustain paces that should feel easier. Demonstrates significant room for improvement through technical work, consistent training volume, and neuromuscular development over time. Economy improvements possible from multiple sources: better mechanics, increased training volume, strength development, years of consistent training.
skills.level2Descriptor: Improving economy as mechanics develop and training volume increases. Moderate energy cost for given pace - still uses more oxygen than highly trained runners but improving. Some inefficiencies remain: occasional overstriding, moderate tension, suboptimal arm action, excessive vertical motion. Biomechanics improving through technical work and motor learning. Beginning economy development through consistent training. Neuromuscular system adapting with training - better muscle fiber recruitment, improving tendon stiffness. Can sustain moderate paces with reasonable effort though still working harder than economical runners at same speed. Shows improvement trajectory with continued training. Economy responding to training volume increases, technical improvements, and time. Demonstrates potential for further development with consistent long-term training.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good running economy for training level enabling competitive performance at club level. Efficient mechanics at normal training paces - reasonable vertical oscillation, good posture, relaxed arms, appropriate stride parameters. Energy cost for speed reasonable though not elite. Consistent training background (multiple years) has produced neuromuscular adaptations improving economy. Can sustain training paces with appropriate effort levels. Biomechanically efficient enough for club-regional competition. Economy enabling competitive performances - can run similar times to athletes with higher VO2 max but poorer economy. Continued improvement potential exists through higher training volumes, advanced technical work, strength training, and additional training years. Demonstrates solid economy foundation with room for advancement.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent running economy competitive at regional-national level. Very efficient mechanics across all training paces - minimal vertical oscillation, optimal stride parameters, relaxed yet powerful movement, biomechanically sound. Low energy cost for speed - uses significantly less oxygen than less economical runners at same pace. Extensive training background (5+ years consistent training) has optimized neuromuscular efficiency. Strong elastic properties in tendons provide energy return. Appropriate strength levels support economical running. Can sustain high paces with lower relative effort than less economical runners. Economy advantage measurable and meaningful - can outperform athletes with higher VO2 max through superior efficiency. Demonstrates advanced training status. Further improvements possible but incremental at this level. Economy among better runners at regional-national level.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class running economy among the most efficient globally. Exceptional efficiency - minimal energy cost for elite speeds. Optimized biomechanics with perfect technique: minimal vertical oscillation, ideal stride parameters, complete relaxation, flawless movement quality. Neuromuscular patterns optimized through years (typically 8-12+ years) of consistent high-level training. Metabolic efficiency maximized - optimal mitochondrial function, ideal substrate utilization, efficient breathing. Perfect elastic properties provide maximal energy return. Strength-to-weight ratio optimized. Can sustain world-class paces with lower oxygen cost than any but the most elite runners globally. Economy advantage decisive at international level - often can compete successfully against athletes with higher VO2 max values. Demonstrates elite training status with long-term optimal development. Among most economical runners in the world. Economy enables Olympic or World Championship performance in endurance events.

skills.name: Lactate Tolerance
skills.level1Descriptor: Very limited lactate tolerance with inability to sustain efforts above threshold intensity. Experiences severe discomfort quickly when lactate begins accumulating, forcing immediate slowing or stopping. Cannot complete even short high-intensity efforts (200-400m) at near-maximum intensity without dramatic pace reduction or walking. Severely ties up (excessive muscle tension and acidosis symptoms) attempting hard efforts. No training history in lactate tolerance work - has not developed physiological or mental adaptations for tolerating acidosis. Cannot maintain running form when experiencing lactate accumulation - stride collapses, arms flail, posture deteriorates completely. Mental toughness insufficient to push through discomfort. Demonstrates fundamental limitation in both physiological tolerance and psychological resilience for high-intensity suffering. Performance in 400m-800m events severely limited by lactate intolerance.
skills.level2Descriptor: Basic lactate tolerance developing but limited capacity. Can complete short high-intensity efforts (200-400m) but with significant discomfort and moderate pace reduction. Experiences considerable tying up during hard efforts though not complete collapse. Beginning to develop some buffering capacity and mental toughness for tolerating acidosis. Can complete lactate tolerance workouts (400m, 600m, 800m repetitions at hard intensity) but requires extended recovery and cannot maintain quality across many repetitions. Form deteriorates noticeably when lactate accumulates but doesn't completely break down. Shows improvement with training but substantial development needed. Mental approach improving - learning that discomfort is manageable and temporary. Demonstrates potential for further development with consistent high-intensity training and mental training.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good lactate tolerance for competition level enabling competent performance in 400m-800m events. Can sustain race-pace intensity for full competition distance with manageable discomfort. Demonstrates adequate buffering capacity to maintain effort despite lactate accumulation. Mental toughness sufficient to push through significant discomfort during races and hard workouts. Can complete quality lactate tolerance sessions - multiple 400m, 600m, or 800m repetitions at race pace with controlled recovery. Form deteriorates moderately when fatigued but maintains reasonable mechanics throughout effort. Competitive at club-regional level in events requiring lactate tolerance. Understands the discomfort is temporary and can be managed. Shows appropriate balance between physiological tolerance and mental resilience. Can complete races without giving in to urge to slow down prematurely.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent lactate tolerance competitive at regional-national level in middle-distance events. Can sustain very high intensity throughout 400m or 800m with superior ability to maintain pace despite severe metabolic stress. Strong buffering capacity minimizes acidosis effects on muscle function. Mental toughness exceptional - can push through extreme discomfort that would force most athletes to slow down. Can complete demanding lactate tolerance workouts maintaining quality across multiple high-intensity repetitions. Form degrades minimally even when experiencing significant lactate accumulation. Demonstrates competitive advantage in 400m-800m through superior tolerance for metabolic stress. Can repeatedly race these events with quick recovery. Mental approach sophisticated - uses strategies to manage discomfort and maintain focus on performance. Serves as model for mental and physical toughness in high-intensity events.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class lactate tolerance among the best globally for middle-distance events. Can sustain elite pace throughout 400m or 800m despite extreme metabolic stress that would incapacitate less tolerant athletes. Exceptional buffering capacity minimizes acidosis impact. Mental toughness at international level - can tolerate pain and discomfort that separates champions from competitors. Maintains biomechanically perfect form even during Olympic or World Championship 400m/800m finals under maximum metabolic stress. Can complete world-class lactate tolerance training maintaining quality throughout sessions. Demonstrates elite-level ability to perform optimally despite severe acidosis. Mental approach mastered - uses sophisticated psychological strategies to manage extreme discomfort. Serves as international model for lactate tolerance. Among the most tolerant athletes globally to metabolic stress. Enables championship performance in events requiring sustained high-intensity effort above lactate threshold.

skills.name: Recovery Ability
skills.level1Descriptor: Poor recovery ability limiting training capacity and adaptation. Requires very extended rest between interval repetitions - may need 5-10 minutes between moderate efforts. Cannot train on consecutive days without severe fatigue accumulation. Single hard session requires 3-5 days recovery before another quality workout possible. Soreness persists for many days after hard training. Heart rate recovery slow - takes 5+ minutes to return to near-baseline after hard effort. Sleep may be disrupted after hard training. No recovery practices employed (stretching, foam rolling, ice baths, compression, etc.). Nutrition and hydration habits poor. Training frequency limited to 2-3 sessions per week maximum due to inadequate recovery. Demonstrates fundamental limitation in recovery capacity restricting training load and adaptation potential. Chronic fatigue common if attempts to train more frequently or intensely.
skills.level2Descriptor: Moderate recovery ability improving with training adaptation. Requires substantial rest between interval repetitions but improving - 3-5 minutes between efforts. Can train on consecutive days occasionally but requires frequent rest days to avoid excessive fatigue. Hard session requires 2-3 days before another quality workout possible. Soreness typical for 2-3 days after hard training but manageable. Heart rate recovery improving - returns to reasonable level within 3-5 minutes. Beginning to implement basic recovery practices inconsistently. Nutrition and hydration improving but not optimized. Can train 3-5 sessions per week with careful management. Shows improvement trajectory as training status develops. Demonstrates better recovery capacity than beginner but still limits training progression. Fatigue management requires attention and planning.
skills.level3Descriptor: Good recovery ability enabling consistent training at club level. Requires moderate rest between interval repetitions appropriate for intensity - 2-4 minutes typically sufficient. Can train on consecutive days regularly with appropriate load management. Hard session requires 1-2 days before another quality session, can do easy runs between. Soreness present but resolves within 24-48 hours typically. Heart rate recovery good - returns to near-baseline within 2-3 minutes after efforts. Implements recovery practices reasonably - stretches, rolls, adequate sleep most nights. Nutrition and hydration generally appropriate. Can train 5-7 sessions per week with proper periodization. Recovery capacity supports club-regional level training loads. Demonstrates appropriate balance between training stress and recovery. Rarely experiences overwhelming fatigue with sensible training progression. Can compete on consecutive days if needed with reasonable performance maintenance.
skills.level4Descriptor: Excellent recovery ability enabling high training loads at regional-national level. Requires minimal rest between interval repetitions - ready for next effort within 1-3 minutes depending on intensity. Can train twice daily when appropriate with good quality in both sessions. Hard session requires only 1 day before another quality session, can do moderate training between. Soreness minimal and resolves quickly (within 24 hours typically). Heart rate recovery very quick - returns to near-baseline within 90-120 seconds. Implements comprehensive recovery practices consistently - quality sleep prioritized, nutrition optimized, stretching/rolling routine, other modalities as needed. Can train 7-12+ sessions per week (including doubles) with proper planning. Recovery capacity supports national-level training loads (80-100+ miles per week for distance runners). Demonstrates superior recovery enabling high training volumes and frequencies. Can compete multiple times per week if necessary with minimal performance decrement.
skills.level5Descriptor: World-class recovery ability enabling elite training loads at international level. Requires very minimal rest between interval repetitions - ready within 60-90 seconds even after hard efforts. Can train twice daily regularly with high quality throughout. Hard sessions can be performed frequently (potentially daily with appropriate planning) due to exceptional recovery capacity. Soreness minimal or absent even after very hard training. Heart rate recovery exceptionally quick - returns to near-baseline within 60 seconds.
